extractions.description: The paper introduces MOSAD, a multi-head open-set time-series anomaly detector, incorporating generative, discriminative, and anomaly-aware contrastive heads to address the challenge of detecting both seen and unseen anomalies.

title.justification: Provided in the user's prompt and in the header of the paper.

type.justification: The paper presents extensive experiments on real-world datasets to validate the proposed MOSAD model.
type.quote: Extensive experiments on three real-world datasets establish MOSAD as a new state-of-the-art in the TSAD field.

research_field.justification: The paper focuses on improving time-series anomaly detection using deep learning models.
research_field.quote: The proposed method, called Multivariate Open-Set time-series Anomaly Detector (MOSAD), is a novel multi-head framework that incorporates a Generative, a Discriminative, and a novel Anomaly-Aware Contrastive head.

sub_research_field.justification: The main focus is on detecting anomalies in multivariate time-series data.
sub_research_field.quote: This paper is the first to address the open-set TSAD problem, in which a small number of labeled anomalies are introduced in the training phase in order to achieve superior anomaly detection performance compared to both supervised and unsupervised TSAD algorithms.

name.justification: MOSAD is explicitly proposed, described, and evaluated in the paper.
name.quote: The proposed method, called Multivariate Open-Set time-series Anomaly Detector (MOSAD), is a novel multi-head framework that incorporates a Generative, a Discriminative, and a novel Anomaly-Aware Contrastive head.

type.justification: MOSAD is built using a combination of a generative model, discriminative model, and contrastive learning framework, all of which are neural network-based methods.
type.quote: We propose MOSAD, trained in an open-set environment, where normal data and a small number of labeled anomalies from a limited class of anomalies are used during training, with the goal of effectively detecting both seen and unseen anomaly classes.

name.justification: TCN is used as the feature extractor in the MOSAD model.
name.quote: we utilize a temporal convolutional network (TCN) [Bai et al., 2018] as our feature extractor, which is a widely recognized choice in the field.

type.justification: TCN is a type of neural network architecture utilized for sequence modeling tasks.
type.quote: we utilize a temporal convolutional network (TCN) [Bai et al., 2018] as our feature extractor, which is a widely recognized choice in the field.

name.justification: Used in the Generative head of MOSAD for learning normal patterns.
name.quote: We employ a generative approach based on the autoencoder framework that consists of an encoder and a decoder.

type.justification: Autoencoders are specific types of neural networks used for unsupervised learning.
type.quote: We employ a generative approach based on the autoencoder framework that consists of an encoder and a decoder.

name.justification: SMD is mentioned as one of the primary datasets on which experiments were conducted.
PTB-XL is mentioned as one of the datasets used for evaluation in the paper.

name.value: Temple University Hospital Electroencephalogram Seizure Corpus (TUSZ)
name.justification: TUSZ is used as one of the datasets for experiments in the paper.
name.quote: Temple University Hospital Electroencephalogram Seizure Corpus (TUSZ) [Shah et al., 2018]
